answers.answer: It its there all the time and never goes away I would not think it likely a migraine.If it persists I think you next step might be to see a retina specialist or a neuroophthalmologist.Find one at www.aao.orgJCH MD
Thank you, Dr HagenThe doctor did a very thorough exam - and he assured me my retinas were fine. if there was some type of occlusion, would he have been able to tell?ThanksMelinda
thank you. that's a relief.is the retina transparent? can you see all the layers with one of those lenses that are held to the eye? or is that what OCTs are for?

Yes the retina is normally transparent. OCT looks at eye tissue on a micrscopic basis looking for swelling, abnormal bleeding, tumors, glaucoma damage, etc. OCT looks under the surface. The indirect ophthalmoloscope (lens held near eye) looks at the surface of the retina.JCH MD
